segments.text: You ask me a question like this, it sounds like a lot of ego.
Well, it's true, but I dare say most of it by far was sincere ego on the parts of all the rivals.
Or sincere concern.
Some.
Picky-oonish and absolutely unreasonable.
Okay.
Who were those some?
I'd say the lesser informed and lesser capable.
It'd be hard to pick out an individual by name, and I'd say it's unreasonable.
It's the old story, just a man is, by the time you spent your whole career in the service and been indoctrinated in the doctrines and principles
It's difficult to make a man change his mind.
Now, one of the things we were taught in Air War College is there's certain doctrines and principles and strategies.
Now, the question that's always raised, and this was obvious in the Southeast Asian War, because a lot of technological advances were made, is does
weapon systems and new innovations in weapon systems dictate strategy, or does strategy dictate weapon systems?
This isn't a black and white, this doesn't require a black and white answer, and there is no black and white answer.
The actual answer is both.
It just depends.
Now, certainly, the atomic bomb
a nuclear armament, there's no doubt it dictates strategy.
A laser-guided bomb, let's say that is a little bit different.
Let's say that has an impact on tactics.
But there's always this question here in which the generals are going to disagree and discuss or debate or argue.
Right.
But this doesn't change principles in command and the influence of people and the use of people who make decisions.
For instance, you can induce all the computers you want, but they handle data.
It's the decision the man makes, the commander makes.
I'm getting to the specific part of the commander of all air.
One man has to do all these things.
And there's one man that should do it.
Now, he can delegate certain things to certain areas and certain times, but one man has to do that, one air commander.
The solution that was finally arrived at in Southeast Asia, to the best of my knowledge, was that all coordination was done at AT, at 7th Air Force.
I don't remember, I believe, I think General O'Meara did get a naval guy in his headquarters, if you will, a naval liaison officer.
Now, I know there was one at- By the way, I think you said this before, but his headquarters was in Saigon, wasn't it?
Where was his headquarters?
At Tonsenute Air Base in Saigon.
Okay.
As well as General Westmoreland.
Oh, yeah, yeah.
He was right with Westmoreland.
Right, right.
There was practically Jason one of them.
But the coordination of, for instance, the selection of targets and all.
Now, this was primarily done by General .
And the man that selects the targets and sets up the rules of engagement, now that, you might say, is the commander.
He really has command then.
Well, let's talk about Mollmeyer.
We've talked about him, and I want to talk about some of his personalities here.
We've mentioned a lot of very important people here, and I want to talk about them and get your impressions or opinions of them.
And let's start with him, Mollmeyer.
Well, I knew him.
What type of person was he?
He was a very private person, very dedicated.
Matter of fact, a hard man to meet.
I often thought Spike must have been an awful, awful lonely person.
Now, a commander is a lonely person.
Speaking generally, he is a lonely man, a commander is.
But General Moltmeyer was, he didn't mix well.
He didn't have a engaging personality at all.
He was just plain old devoted, I mean,
Is there a stronger word than devoted or dedicated?
You name it.
That's what he was to his job.
He literally lived, ate, slept his job.
Did he have a sense of humor?
Yeah, he did.
As a matter of fact, I knew him personally.
And we'd sit down, we'd laugh, and we'd make jokes.
And we'd laugh about some of the things.
He'd laugh about some of his problems.
really.
But when it got down to, you know, solving the problem or all, he's all business.
He's all business.
And particularly in staff meetings.
He wouldn't prevent smoking in staff meetings.
There's a lot of them like that.
He drank very little.
He was, he had an unusually good memory.
He had
Facts and figures at hand that would just astound you.
To give you an example of how good he was, when General Ryan took over command of the Pacific Air Forces, see in effect, Seventh Air Force had a certain responsibility to him, but
in a chain of command, and General Ryan was a very strong man, and of course was General Momar, extremely strong, strong will.
And General Ryan and General Momar clashed immediately, and to the point where, through General Ryan's orders, Momar took a trip back to USAF headquarters.
Really?
Yes, sir.
It is called by General McConnell.
to report General McConnell.
And talk about this?
Yes, sir.
And if I went back, you know, feeling ill, I'm going to be relieved.
Was he?
No.
Matter of fact, to make a long story short, before General Mulmire left Washington, DC, he got clear up to the level and briefed President Roosevelt personally on the war.
Johnson?
Johnson.
Johnson.
I'm sorry.
And went back to his job for the blessings of General McConnell.
And General McConnell called General Ryan Person on the phone and said, Jack, you forget about General McConnell.
He went over there and says, this is the first man I've ever seen that could out-talk and out-reason McNamara.
No kidding?
Yes, sir.
He had more facts and figures and could
talk statistics better than that.
That's how good he was.
Okay, let's talk about Mollmeyer's relations with Westmoreland.
I'm sure you met Westmoreland a number of times.
He and General Westmoreland had a very healthy respect for General Mollmeyer, and General Mollmeyer was instrumental.
As a matter of fact, he and General Westmoreland were
completely together on, you know, how to control SACS missions in South Vietnam, the giant strikes, you know, against the Viet Cong camps.
So, and also, General Westmoreland and Ambassador Sullivan were, I don't think two people could be more hostile and hated each other more than those two did.
And I actually used my headquarters one time for a meeting at directions of
for their meeting about coordination of operations in Laos.
They came to my headquarters.
General Sullivan wouldn't permit him to come in Laos.
Why'd they hate each other so much?
Well, General Ed, well, to quote, I sat in on the meeting because I was the host, if you will.
And General Mowmeyer, by the way, accompanied Admiral General Westmoreland and sat there.
And it was obvious, you know, Mowmeyer said- When they met each other, would they shake hands?
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
They were, you know, civil to each other.
But when you get to the meeting and start talking about things, and this is where the- Recount the meeting.
I'm going to do that.
To make a long story short, they started arguing about General Westmoreland wanting to put forces into Laos.
He had to expand the area against Viet Cong and hit the supply bases.
See, he reasoned, like any general, you've got to hit him at his source and interdict his supply line.
This got over into Laos.

and said, well, there's certain things, you know, that I'm boss in Laos, and there's certain rules, you know, we've got to follow, and we don't want to spread this war, and then, you know, this got into really argument, and both were expounding their views and trying to settle a problem, and General Westmoreland said, well, I'm the commander over here, and
I've got authority to do this."
And Ambassador Sullivan says, well, I'm the commander and the boss in Laos and nobody does anything in Laos without my approval.
Well, this is how.
No kidding.
And this just turned out to be an impasse and that's what left.
Did they start shouting at each other?
Oh yeah.
They both got real heated.
Oh yeah.
Well, it was a very heated debate.
But they left civility to one another, naturally.
And they couldn't resolve the issue.
No.
It would go to a higher level anyway, didn't it?
It did go up to a higher level, and that's the way it was resolved.
And Sullivan won?
Well, the decision was eventually to put forces into Laos after I went home.
Yeah, later.
Later.
When Nixon became president.
Nixon was president.
As a matter of fact, General Stilwell at Matai was all for this idea, too.
But, see, he was trained by General Westmoreland.
At one time, he was chief of staff of Armed Forces South Vietnam under Westmoreland.
And when this job came open in Thailand, Westmoreland sent him over there with the idea of controlling what's going on in Thailand also.
Now, during this meeting, were they swearing at each other?
No, no.
And every once in a while.
Did you have to cool them down?
Oh, no.
I didn't open my mouth in this meeting.
I just provided my office, coffee, and a chair.
And very highly entertained and amused.
And once all over, of course, the gentleman O'Meara didn't pass.
And I was escorting him to the airplane.
And actually, we laughed and grinned about it.
In front of Westmoreland you're laughing?
Oh yeah.
I think actually in, I think, well I actually think they shook hands and left.
Sullivan and Westmoreland.
And Spike and I, General O'Meara and I were laughing about it.
And of course General O'Meara, you know he, General O'Meara supported General Westmoreland.
So to get back to your basic question, in a lot of ways, see, Westmoreland and General O'Meara were in the same boat.
So they got along okay.
What was your opinion of Westmoreland?
Very controversial figure in America at this time.
I think he was a very egotistical person and vain type of a person, but I even think it turned out, you know, he had aspirations to be President of the United States.
You think he did?
Oh, yes.
But, uh,

I learned to know General Westmoreland in exercises in the United States way before he went over to Southeast Asia, and he was a very controversial man in those exercises about who would control the air transport in the landing zone of the Florida area of exercise, the Army or the Air Force.
He was definitely an Army man, died in the World Army.
all of the philosophy of the Air Force, particularly for close air support.
He was instrumental in a lot in the Army getting on to their current helicopter combat operations.
Do you think that he was a pompous man?
He wasn't as pompous as
For instance, the Ambassador Graham Martin.
Okay, well we're going to get into him.
Did he have a sense of humor?
Oh, yeah.
Westmoreland did?
He was articulate, very articulate.
He was strong-willed.
He wasn't as quiet
He mixed more easily with, he was more of a social man than Mowmire was.
He was more of a diplomat.
He had diplomacy.
General Mowmire would never be a diplomat in the State Department.
Never.
Westmoreland could be a diplomat.
He could be an ambassador.
General Mowmire could.
OK.
Who was the ambassador in Thailand, later became the ambassador, and the last ambassador in Vietnam?
Ambassador Grant Martin was a career diplomat and a very capable person, in my opinion.
And you might say he was, I won't say he was a typical member of the State Department,
Many people have a different idea of what a State Department man is.
He was a good ambassador.
He did wonders for Thailand.
They loved him.
He was really dedicated to his mission to help the Thais.
And I agreed with everything he wanted to do.
What did he want to do?
He wanted to give the Thai Armed Forces more capability.
He sincerely believed that there was
encroachment of North Vietnamese insurgents across the border from Laos into Thailand.
I agreed with him.
He wanted to give the Thai air forces and the Thai police a capability with helicopters to combat them.
He fought the certain elements of the, well, he fought McNamara primarily and his thoughts in Washington
because McNamara primarily thought that the threat to Thailand was way under overdone by the Thais and their demand for military aid, and that Ambassador Martin supported them.
Therefore, he didn't agree with it.
It came so intense that Secretary McNamara would never come to Thailand.
He wouldn't enter Thailand.
Graham Martin didn't want him in Thailand.

Matter of fact, whether Graham Martin had the authority to keep him from coming to Thailand, I don't know, but I know he never did come, and I know that's exactly the way the ambassador felt about him.
There was extreme hostility there, and it showed in wires that I was privy to read that he sent back to Washington.
Ambassador Martin, and perhaps rightly so, he felt he was the representative of the president
He was not a representative of the State Department.
He was a representative of the President, and he did what he thought the President would do in Thailand.
This was not too apparent in the way Ambassador Sullivan felt.
I guess Ambassador Sullivan didn't feel that strongly about his responsibility.
He honored the Secretary of State, perhaps, let's say,
That's the impression I got, much more so than did Ambassador Grant Martin.
Now, I asked about pomposity, and you said Martin.
Yes, he was.
He was a, in my opinion, and I don't say this critically, but pompous describes his personality in a lot of cases, particularly when dealing with subordinates.
I have observed him in the presence of the king and queen and the ministers and high officials of Thailand.
And he was a very polite and courteous and, oh, not servile, but very proper, if you will, diplomat-wise, very proper.
But to subordinate, definitely pompous.
He, as much as he liked and respected me, and that man wrote wires on me recommending me for promotion on the spot.
That's how much he admired me.
No kidding?
Yes, sir.
Why?
He admired me.
Why?
Because I supported him.
In my respect to him as my boss, I supported him.
I actually argued for some of his desires and ideas with my other bosses.
He knew I was there.
He trusted me completely.

And one of my other bosses, like General Wilson, 13th Air Force Commander, I actually heard him say to General McConnell and to General Ryan, General Harris, the Pacific Air Force Commander, that this guy has got the ambassadors eating out of his hand.
You did?
That's what he said.
He said that to me.
I mean, he said that to them about me.
He said, this guy, Charlie, he got these ambassadors.
He handed his hand.
Well, be that as it may, let's say I was just doing my job.
But both Ambassador Sullivan and Ambassador Martin, I have to say I respect them because they
They admired me and we established a rapport and friendship.
Now there's something, the way they did and operate, I didn't agree with.
Like what?
I don't agree with the way, I don't agree with the way, the abruptness of Ambassador Grant Martin with his subordinates and staff.
I don't think he knew how to handle people properly.
At least he didn't handle them the way I would handle people.
He was too jealous of his prerogatives.

I feel, Terry, that a man that has authority, when he has to exercise it to get things done with people he's talking to, when he has to exercise his authority to get things done, then I don't consider this real leadership.
And I take General Eisenhower.
Oh, we're going to talk about leaders later.
Okay.
But I agree.
I mean, I have read accounts of when Graham Martin was ambassador of Vietnam, written by his subordinates, and they bring out these things how they didn't like the man being his subordinate.
I can understand that.
You can understand.
Okay, now let's compare Graham Martin with Bill Sullivan.
Well, Graham Martin, of course, was a much older man.
And in physical stature, he was a much taller man and looked more elderly.
And in a lot of ways, the way he appeared, let's say, a little bit more statesman-like.
Statesmanship, if you will.
Ambassador Sullivan was a younger man, very ambitious.
but equally as zealous of his authority as Ambassador Martin.
Equally, both of them, very zealous of his authority.
But so was Beaumont, so was Westmoreland, so was General Stilwell, and who knows, maybe Charlie Bond.
But nevertheless, to answer your question,
ambitious.
He was extremely articulate.
He was known for his sarcasm and his wires to Washington, D.C.
It was strange the way
why he did it, I don't know, but maybe it was a characteristic that identified him and separated him apart from other people.
But many people talked about the characteristics of his cables going back to Washington.
Very satirical or sarcastic or describing his
Feelings about a problem or a relationship with other people.
It's difficult for me to think right now of an example.
How did he get along with other people?
7th Air Force staff hated his guts.
As a matter of fact, they made a comment to me on one visit where I was trying to coordinate efforts.
And I think I made the comment.
And President General Lamar and his staff
You see, I was responsible for General Momar as Water Sullivan.
And I said to somebody, well, now you've got to put yourself in Ambassador Sullivan's position.
He's got his responsibility.
He's got to do certain things.
And I think, sincerely, he realizes General Momar's responsibilities.
And he recognizes them.
What did Momar say to that?
Momar didn't say anything.
But one of his staff said, well, I'll tell you this.
How did he put it?
if we need more friends like him, I'd rather have enemies or something to that extent.
That was indicative of how much they had a distaste for him.
There's a staff for him.
But this, again, was, you know, supporting Don Omar and what they knew of his function.
These are understandable remarks for people who don't know the entire story.
Sure.
Sounds like you're balancing that because it took up most of your time.
It did.
That's the reason I was given the job.
Okay, now did Rusk ever come over there, Dean Rusk, Secretary of State under Johnson?
Did he ever come over?
No.
You never met him?
I never met him in time.
Okay, let's talk about a man who's very controversial, especially with the military, and that's Secretary of Defense McNamara.
Oh, indeed, I can understand that.
I've already told you a story about General Lamar.
You already told me about him and McNamara, and you also told me that Graham Martin wouldn't even let him into the country.
Did you ever meet McNamara?
No, not to shake his hand or meet him in a social gathering, but I have seen him at a site.
I only know him by what I
by hearing him on TV or radio or by reading his wires or reading about him.
Well, I'm sure that Momar must have had some words to you about McNamara.
And Westmoreland, they must have made some comments about McNamara.
I think General Westmoreland, if I remember correctly, I think General Westmoreland probably
I'm not going to say.
I don't know how General Westmoreland felt about McNamara, but General Momar- He never made a statement?
Westmoreland never made a statement about McNamara?
Not in my presence.
Oh, okay.
Oh, I've read a lot about him.
Yeah, okay.
But you want what I know.
Yeah.
What did Momar say in your presence?
In my, best of my memory, Momar, well, I know he did not like McNamara.
Mm-hmm.
And-
And you recall, I told you, he briefed McNamara.
He went from McConnell to the JCS chairman to McNamara to President Johnson.
And I think McNamara had respect for Omar.
He must have after that meeting.
But Spike didn't care for him.
And for the reasons that you and I have read about McNamara.
Secretary, and this again is my opinion, I've never met the man, but based on
hearing other people talk who had been in meetings with him and knowing him and talking about him.
I guess the best way to drive it, Secretary McNamara wasn't near as smart as he thought he was.
And I think history proved that statement.
And there again is a man that's put in charge of a job that goes out on his own without accepting
the experience and know-how of people who've been in the business and made serious mistakes.
I think that's very important.
And I'll bet you, if you talked to Secretary McNamara today, I bet you he'd admit it.
In other words, listening to people like Momar and other generals, it appeared that McNamara just didn't listen to the professionals in the service.
Is that true?
Anybody.
He listened to anybody, in my opinion.
And he certainly didn't take advice of the professionals in the field.
Neither did his so-called whiz kid gang.
There seems to be a lot of tension between the whiz kids and McNamara and the generals.
Is that true?
In those days, too.
The way information's hefted down to me during those years, I bet it's true.
And the things that you heard and the...
read, you know, you reach much of it where the smoke is fire.
It had to be there.
There's no doubt Secretary McNamara had to be a very capable man as far as memory is concerned, analyzing a problem, and dedicated to his job, ability to absorb facts.
I just think his biggest deficiency is that he just didn't accept the fact that experienced military men under him did know what was going on and actually were honest.
Sometimes I must think he doubted the honesty of a lot of people under him.
Did you ever receive a survey by a Brigadier General in the Army named Douglas Kinnard about your role in Southeast Asia?
Kinnard?
K-I-N-N-A-R-D.
Ask me that question again.
Did you ever receive a survey after you retired by a Brigadier General who served in Vietnam named Douglas Kinnard?
There was another major...
But you said about me.
No, about America's role in Vietnam.
Oh, no.
I've heard the word, but no, I don't know.
I don't think I have.
Because this man wrote a book entitled The War Managers based on a number of generals who served in Vietnam and their answers to his long question here about what went wrong in Vietnam.
And I was just wondering.
No, I've never seen it.
The big question here, of course, and this is a question for historians and military
military professionals and for future planning is why did we lose that war?
What's your opinion?
Well, I can certainly understand the question and it rightfully should be asked.

There's probably a lot of facts that I don't know that cause people at higher levels, and I'm talking about presidential and secretary levels, civilian, presidential and secretary levels in Washington, D.C., that I don't know.
I'm sure there are some things I don't know, many things.

I've had enough experience in my Russian tour and my Southeast Asian tour in dealing with high level civilian authorities to know that there's things that are going on at higher levels that we at the lower levels never get word of.

based on what I know and analysis and I've asked myself this question many many times and gone through a lot of soul touching about it and I think the best way to try to categorically answer your question is that had the had the will from the president right on down
been made and existed that we're in a war and we're going to win it and I'm going to tell the military to win this war and let them go and do it, that war would have been over easily in six months.
Easily in six months.
This was not done.
There may be a reason for it.
Namely, maybe there was justification for fear of China.
being brought in across into North Vietnam and broadening the war.
Maybe there was justification for it.
At my level, and as hindsight proves now, definitely there was none.
I don't think China would have.
And I'm sure at a presidential level, I've been in command position to know that you have responsibility.
I'm sure that you have to consider that it's my job not to let this war spread.
It's my job to keep my people from being killed and save lives as much as possible.
But it must be also his responsibility
to win that war and bring it to a close as soon as possible.
I think this was a no-er.
That's the best way I can categorically answer.
So you put your responsibility on the politicians?
I do, categorically.
And it's one of the blackest spots on the history of this country in my life.
Now watch your opinion.
What do you think?
that you could have done from Thailand, which would have expedited the victory?
From Thailand, in my position?
In your position.
Practically nothing.
But if I had been put in a position, let's say, higher up, maybe as Biden's President of the United States, let's say, as Secretary of Defense, or as Secretary of State, or as Chairman of the JCS.
Then maybe you could have done something.
I would have certainly recommended something.
Okay, and as far as, but as far as Thailand, and as far as your job, your position in Thailand, you did everything, everything possible to win.
Oh, absolutely.
Absolutely.
Matter of fact.
And there couldn't have been anything else more.
I mean, you couldn't have done anything else, expand the effort or anything.
There was no politicians holding you back, right?
Politicians holding me back?
No.
No.
No.
OK, so you did everything possible.
But if you're asked a question like this, if I violated instructions and scrambled, OK, I know you're not.
Because some military men, like we just talked about, like Westmoreland, these people complained, especially after they came back to the United States, that they were not allowed to win the war.
I did everything I could without violating orders.
What were some of the orders that you would have liked to have seen withdrawn?
I would have liked to have seen the
Reins, R-E-I-N-S, taken off of air power.
And General Mollmeyer given instructions to hit the enemy the way you think best to stop this supply of South Vietnam and stop this war.
You go.
That's the way I'd like to see it done.
It would have been over in six months.
What targets did Mollmeyer hit, then?
He would have hit...

uh well the uh obviously the dams for instance he had been turned loose on the dams he'd been turned loose on the uh haiphong port you know which we one president finally said hit it uh see we got close to using their power the way we should have used it he would have choked off the the railroad from china proper down into hanoi into north vietnam
He would have completely interdicted the supply of North Vietnam, cut them off from the supply of all of their supporters, China, Russia, and whoever chipped stuff in from ports.
As a matter of fact, you look back now, and it's
been said by many who apparently know the facts better than I, that had we continued the B-52 bombing of North Vietnam another few months, it would probably change the course of the entire war.
Have you ever heard that?
Yeah, I've heard that.
Ain't no doubt in my mind it would have.
Listen, as a supposition, it's hard to say.
Well, we don't want to get into a probable debate here.
I just wanted to know your opinion on that.
Yes, sir.
Could you all eat a bowl of chili with your sandwich, Jerry?
Do you like chili?
Sure, I'd love it.
Oh, another thing.
Let me tell you.
I would have changed the rules of engagement to take off all of the restrictions for the fighter bombers.
I quoted a couple of these to you.
I would have given the Air Force much more freedom to hit the enemy no matter where they were in Laos.
I would have given Westmoreland the right to send forces into Laos.
I would have engaged forces and laid on an invasion plan of North Vietnam instead of fighting in South Vietnam in a jungle.
That's what I would have done.
Like MacArthur did in North Vietnam, I mean Korea.
He invaded the place up there.
How about the use of nuclear weapons?
There wasn't a target in North Vietnam worthy of a nuclear weapon.
Psychologically, I think it would have been abused.
That, now, is one thing I would not agree to.
Were I the president, I would never agree to use a nuclear weapon in North Vietnam.
I mean in the Southeast Asia.
Have you ever heard of this so-called McNamara Wall?
Oh, yeah.
I think I know what you're talking about.
Deploying a wall of troops across from the coast over into Laos into Thailand?
Mm-hmm.
Yeah, I've heard of it.
Most asinine thing I've ever heard in my life.
Matter of fact, I'm not sure it's called a McNamara Wall.
I think this was pushed to a certain extent by the Army in...
forces of John Westmoreland.
Okay.
What did you think of it?
You thought of it.
Why?
Why?
I'm sure that had that been done, that, well, there wouldn't have been enough forces left to do any fighting in the jungle then.
Plus the fact, once you see the area, I think you'd agree with me,
Plus the fact that then, I guess, the North Vietnamese just went around the corner and flew Thailand.
If necessary, it goes right through the border in Burma.
There's not enough forces.
That just reminds me of the marginal wall in France.
OK. We all know how good that worked.
Now, I think we've covered this job.
of yours in Southeast Asia.
Was there anything else before we used to talk about why you left?
No, I think we spent enough time on it.
OK, why did you leave?
It was time to rotate me back home and give some more Air Force generals the experience I'd had.
Matter of fact, I stayed over there a tour and a half.
Really, I stayed over there.
From January 1966 to July 1967, you were in Thailand.
And in July 1967, you took on your last tour of duty to August 68 as the commander's headquarters 12th Air Force in Waco.
Now, what were your feelings when you left Southeast Asia?
Well, being a human being, I was glad to leave, get back home, and particularly get back to my family.
I left with a great deal of pride in what I had accomplished.
I felt that I had done, under the circumstances, quite frankly and not egotistically, I think I had done a better job than even General McConnell had asked me to do, when I think back.
described my job to many general officers, my cohorts, and they, to them it's the most comical thing in the world, and I think, how in the world did you do it?
I was proud of what I'd done.
As a matter of fact, General McConnell subsequently gave me the Distinguished Service Medal, Air Force, for my job.
God bless him.
He awarded me for the job I did.
He gave me my first Air Force command, 12th Air Force.
Okay, now, when you came back from the Flying Tigers, you came back pretty much as a hero in America.
When you came back from Vietnam, how did you come back?
Oh, it's far different.
I came back home and
And I was on leave for about 30 days in the Dallas area.
But it was considerably different.
I was just another officer that had returned from Southeast Asian War and done my tour of duty.
Let's move then into the 12th Air Force.
Tremendous command responsibility.
What was the size of the Air Force in Waco?
The headquarters was probably around 300, 400 people, but my entire command was about, if I remember right, I think it was about 44,500 people.
And it extended from the Mississippi.
How many?
And it extended over a geographical area from the Mississippi to California.
